bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 164, Number 156 (Thursday, September 20, 2018)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. ZELDIN:H.R. 6861.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1, Section 8 of the United States Constitution.____________________[Page H8739]

item.title: Counter Terrorism and Illicit Finance Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

summary.text: This bill directs the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network to issue regulations regarding the issuance of no-action letters in response to inquiries concerning the application of certain anti-money-laundering and counter-terrorist-financing laws or regulations.

bill.title: To amend title 31, United States Code, with respect to FinCEN no-action letters, and for other purposes.

item.title: To amend title 31, United States Code, with respect to FinCEN no-action letters, and for other purposes.
To amend title 31, United States Code, with respect to FinCEN no-action letters, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
